ground_truth: Vincent smiles and Mia giggles as Vincent turns around. We're in the living room of a modest two-bedroom house in Alhambra, California, in the year 1972. Butch's mother, around 35, stands in the doorway leading into the living room, next to a man dressed in the uniform of an American Air Force officer. The camera captures the perspective of a five-year-old boy as Koons steps inside the room toward the child, bending on one knee to match the boy's eyeline. When Koons speaks, he has a slight Texas accent and pulls a gold wristwatch out of his pocket, handing it to Butch. A little hand enters the frame to accept it. The 27-year-old Butch Coolidge is shown dressed in boxing regalia—trunks, shoes, and gloves—lying on a table catching a few zzzz's before a big fight. He wakes up suddenly, shaken by the bizarre memory, and wipes his sweaty face with a boxing glove. His trainer Klondike, an older fireplug, opens the door slightly, peeking into the room as pandemonium breaks out behind him in the hallway. A taxi is parked in a dark alley next to an auditorium, and we slowly dolly toward the parked car while the sound of the car radio is heard from inside. A young woman with Spanish looks sits in the car, drinking steaming hot coffee from a white Styrofoam cup as sportscasters continue their coverage. Esmarelda clicks the radio off, sips her coffee, and hears a noise from behind in the alley. She sticks her head out of the car door to investigate and sees a window about three stories high open on the auditorium side of the alley. A gym bag is tossed out into a garbage dumpster below, followed by Butch Coolidge, still in boxing trunks, shoes, gloves, and a yellow robe, leaping into the dumpster. Esmarelda registers the strangeness of this scene as Butch, soaking wet and naked except for his trunks, shoes, and gloves, hops into the backseat and slams the door. Esmarelda stares straight ahead and talks to Butch through the rearview mirror as he gets one of his boxing gloves off. Esmarelda watches in the rearview mirror, then presses a button to roll down the back window. Butch tosses his boxing glove out, starts untying the other one, and Esmarelda can’t stay quiet anymore. As he tosses his other glove out the window, he finishes wiping himself down and tosses the towel out. Silence ensues as Butch digs in his bag for a t-shirt.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Vincent grins and Mia titters as Vincent pivots around. We're in the lounge of a humble two-bedroom abode in Alhambra, California, in the year 1972. Butch's mother, approximately 35, stands in the entrance leading into the lounge, next to a gentleman attired in the attire of an American Air Force officer. The camera captures the perspective of a five-year-old child as Koons steps inside the chamber toward the youngster, kneeling on one knee to match the child's eyeline. When Koons speaks, he has a faint Texas accent and extracts a gold wristwatch out of his pocket, delivering it to Butch. A small hand enters the frame to receive it. The 27-year-old Butch Coolidge is depicted attired in boxing gear—trunks, shoes, and gloves—reclining on a table catching a few zzzz's before a big bout. He awakens suddenly, disturbed by the peculiar recollection, and wipes his sweaty visage with a boxing glove. His trainer Klondike, an older fireplug, opens the door slightly, peering into the room as bedlam erupts behind him in the corridor. A taxi is stationed in a dim lane next to an auditorium, and we slowly dolly toward the parked vehicle while the sound of the car radio is perceived from inside. A youthful woman with Spanish features sits in the vehicle, sipping steaming hot coffee from a white Styrofoam cup as sportscasters continue their commentary. Esmarelda clicks the radio off, sips her coffee, and hears a sound from behind in the lane. She sticks her head out of the car door to investigate and sees a window about three stories high open on the auditorium side of the lane. A gym bag is flung out into a garbage dumpster below, followed by Butch Coolidge, still in boxing trunks, shoes, gloves, and a yellow robe, vaulting into the dumpster. Esmarelda registers the oddness of this scene as Butch, drenched and nude except for his trunks, shoes, and gloves, hops into the backseat and slams the door. Esmarelda gazes straight ahead and converses with Butch through the rearview mirror as he gets one of his boxing gloves off. Esmarelda watches in the rearview mirror, then presses a button to roll down the back window. Butch flings his boxing glove out, starts untying the other one, and Esmarelda can’t remain quiet anymore. As he flings his other glove out the window, he finishes wiping himself down and flings the towel out. Silence follows as Butch rummages in his bag for a t-shirt.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Vincent's smile is met by Mia’s giggle as a turn is made by Vincent. The living room of a modest two-bedroom house in Alhambra, California, in the year 1972, is where we find ourselves. Butch’s mother, around 35, is standing in the doorway leading into the living room, next to a man who wears the uniform of an American Air Force officer. A five-year-old boy’s perspective is captured by the camera as Koons, stepping inside the room, moves toward the child, bending on one knee to match the boy's eyeline. When a slight Texas accent accompanies Koons' speech, a gold wristwatch is pulled out of his pocket, which is handed to Butch. The frame is entered by a little hand to accept it. Dressed in boxing regalia—trunks, shoes, and gloves—the 27-year-old Butch Coolidge is lying on a table, catching a few zzzz's before a big fight. Suddenly, he is woken by the bizarre memory, and his sweaty face is wiped with a boxing glove. Klondike, his trainer, an older fireplug, slightly opens the door, peeking into the room as pandemonium breaks out behind him in the hallway. A taxi, parked in a dark alley next to an auditorium, is approached slowly as the sound of the car radio is heard from inside. In the car, a young woman with Spanish looks drinks steaming hot coffee from a white Styrofoam cup as sportscasters continue their coverage. The radio is clicked off by Esmarelda, who sips her coffee and hears a noise from behind in the alley. She sticks her head out of the car door to investigate and sees a window about three stories high being opened on the auditorium side of the alley. A gym bag is tossed out into a garbage dumpster below, followed by Butch Coolidge, still in boxing trunks, shoes, gloves, and a yellow robe, who leaps into the dumpster. The strangeness of this scene is registered by Esmarelda as Butch, soaking wet and naked except for his trunks, shoes, and gloves, hops into the backseat and slams the door. Esmarelda stares straight ahead and talks to Butch through the rearview mirror as one of his boxing gloves is removed by him. In the rearview mirror, Esmarelda watches, then presses a button to roll down the back window. His boxing glove is tossed out by Butch, who starts untying the other one, and Esmarelda can't stay quiet anymore. As his other glove is tossed out the window by him, finishing wiping himself down, and the towel is tossed out. Silence ensues as a t-shirt is dug out by Butch from his bag.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Vincent smiles and Mia giggles as Vincent turns around in the living room of a modest house in Alhambra, California, circa 1972. Butch's mother, around 35, stands with a man in an American Air Force officer uniform. The scene captures the view of a five-year-old boy as Koons enters, kneels, and with a slight Texas accent, hands a gold wristwatch to Butch. A small hand accepts it. Butch Coolidge, aged 27, dressed in boxing gear, catches sleep on a table before a fight. He jolts awake from a strange memory, wiping his sweaty face with a boxing glove. His trainer Klondike peeks in as chaos erupts behind him in the hallway. A taxi is parked in a dark alley beside an auditorium. A young Hispanic woman drinks coffee in the car, listening to sports coverage. Esmarelda turns off the radio, hears a noise, and sees a window open three stories high. Butch, only in trunks, shoes, gloves, and a yellow robe, leaps into a dumpster. Esmarelda notes the oddity as Butch, now soaking wet, hops into the backseat. Esmarelda watches through the rearview mirror as Butch removes a boxing glove and throws it out. She rolls down the back window, and Butch discards the glove and towel, digging for a t-shirt in silence.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Vincent smiles and Mia giggles as Vincent turns around in the Alhambra, California, living room of a modest two-bedroom house in 1972. Butch's 35-year-old mother stands by an American Air Force officer. The camera shows a five-year-old boy's view as Koons enters, kneels, and hands Butch a gold wristwatch. Butch, now 27, is asleep in boxing gear before a fight, jolted by a memory, wiping sweat with a glove. Trainer Klondike peeks in, chaos behind him, as a taxi waits in a dark alley by an auditorium. Spanish-looking Esmarelda drinks hot coffee, listens to sportscasters, and hears a noise. She sees a window open, a gym bag, then Butch in boxing gear jumps into a dumpster. Esmarelda notes the oddity as Butch, dripping and in trunks, shoes, gloves, and yellow robe, enters the backseat. She talks to Butch via the rearview mirror while he removes his glove. She rolls down the window, and Butch throws out his glove, unties the other, wipes down, and throws out the towel. Silent, Butch searches for a t-shirt.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Vincent, with a cheerful expression on his face, smiles warmly while Mia, full of delight and amusement, giggles as Vincent makes a turn around the room. We find ourselves situated in the cozy and intimate setting of the living room within a modest two-bedroom house located in Alhambra, California, during the memorable year of 1972. Standing in the doorway that leads directly into the living room is Butch's mother, a woman appearing to be around the age of 35. She is positioned beside a man who is clad in the distinguished uniform of an American Air Force officer. The camera captures this entire scene from the unique perspective of an innocent five-year-old boy as Koons makes his way inside the room, approaching the child and bending down on one knee to align his gaze with the boy's line of sight. As Koons begins to speak, his words carry a subtle Texas twang, and he draws a gold wristwatch out from his pocket, offering it to young Butch. A small, youthful hand enters the frame to accept this meaningful gift. 

The scene shifts to reveal the 27-year-old Butch Coolidge, adorned in his distinctive boxing attire—wearing trunks, boxing shoes, and gloves—lying on a table, attempting to catch some much-needed sleep before the significant fight ahead. Suddenly, he wakes up abruptly, disturbed by the strange and vivid memory, and wipes his perspiring face with one of his boxing gloves. His trainer, Klondike, an older and robust figure, gently opens the door slightly, peering into the room while chaos and pandemonium erupt behind him in the bustling hallway. A taxi is parked inconspicuously in a shadowy alleyway beside an auditorium, and the camera gradually moves forward toward the parked vehicle, while the sound of the car radio resonates from within. Inside the car sits a young woman of Spanish descent, enjoying her steaming hot coffee from a simple white Styrofoam cup as the sportscasters continue their lively coverage. Esmarelda, the young woman, clicks off the radio, takes another sip of her coffee, and then hears an unexpected noise coming from behind her in the alley. Curious, she leans her head out of the car door to investigate and notices a window about three stories high on the auditorium side of the alley swinging open. A gym bag is then tossed out into a garbage dumpster below, quickly followed by Butch Coolidge, still clad in his boxing trunks, shoes, gloves, and a vibrant yellow robe, as he leaps into the dumpster.

Esmarelda, taking in the peculiarity of the situation, registers the strangeness of the scene as she watches Butch, now soaking wet and dressed only in his trunks, shoes, and gloves, clamber into the backseat of her car and slam the door shut. Esmarelda gazes forward, speaking to Butch through the reflection in the rearview mirror while he begins to remove one of his boxing gloves. Observing his actions through the mirror, Esmarelda then presses a button to lower the back window. Butch takes this opportunity to toss his boxing glove out, starting to untie the other one. Esmarelda, finally unable to maintain her silence, speaks up as he disposes of his other glove out the window. Once he finishes drying himself off, he throws the towel out as well. A quiet calm descends as Butch rummages through his bag in search of a t-shirt.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Vincent, a man with a bright and cheerful expression adorning his face, exudes warmth and friendliness as he smiles with genuine joy. At the same time, Mia, who is utterly full of delight and amusement, lets out a giggle in response as Vincent gracefully makes a turn around the room. We find ourselves fully immersed in the cozy and intimate atmosphere of the living room. This is all happening within a modest yet charming two-bedroom house situated in the picturesque town of Alhambra, California, during the truly memorable year of 1972. Positioned right in the doorway that leads directly into this inviting living room stands Butch's mother, a woman who appears to be around the age of 35 years. She is standing beside a man who is wearing the distinguished and recognizable uniform of an American Air Force officer. The camera expertly captures this entire scene from the unique perspective of an innocent five-year-old boy as Koons enters the room, making his way toward the child. Bending down on one knee, he aligns his gaze with the boy's line of sight. As Koons begins to speak, his words are gently laced with a subtle Texas twang, and he carefully draws a gold wristwatch from his pocket, offering it to young Butch. A small, youthful hand then enters the frame, reaching out to accept this meaningful and significant gift.

The scene smoothly transitions to reveal the 27-year-old Butch Coolidge, who is adorned in his distinctive boxing gear—wearing his trunks, boxing shoes, and gloves. He is lying on a table, attempting to catch some much-needed rest before the significant fight that lies ahead. Suddenly, he wakes up abruptly, disturbed by the strange and vivid memory, and he wipes his perspiring face with one of his boxing gloves. His trainer, Klondike, an older and robust figure, gently opens the door slightly, peering into the room as chaos and pandemonium continue to erupt behind him in the bustling hallway. Meanwhile, a taxi is parked inconspicuously in a shadowy alleyway beside an auditorium, and the camera gradually moves forward toward this parked vehicle while the sound of the car radio resonates from within. Inside the car sits a young woman of Spanish descent, who is enjoying her steaming hot coffee from a simple white Styrofoam cup as the sportscasters continue their lively and animated coverage. Esmarelda, the young woman, clicks off the radio, takes another sip of her coffee, and then hears an unexpected and curious noise coming from behind her in the alley. Intrigued, she leans her head out of the car door to investigate and notices a window about three stories high on the auditorium side of the alley swinging open. A gym bag is then tossed out into a garbage dumpster below, quickly followed by Butch Coolidge, still clad in his boxing trunks, shoes, gloves, and a vibrant yellow robe, as he leaps fearlessly into the dumpster.

Esmarelda, taking in the peculiarity and oddity of the situation, registers the strangeness of the scene as she watches Butch, now soaking wet and dressed only in his trunks, shoes, and gloves. He clambers into the backseat of her car and slams the door shut. Esmarelda gazes forward, speaking to Butch through the reflection in the rearview mirror while he starts to remove one of his boxing gloves. Observing his actions closely through the mirror, Esmarelda then presses a button to lower the back window. Butch takes this opportunity to toss his boxing glove out, and he begins to untie the other one carefully. Esmarelda, finally unable to maintain her silence any longer, speaks up as he disposes of his other glove out the window. Once he finishes drying himself off, he throws the towel out as well. A quiet calm descends as Butch rummages through his bag, searching for a t-shirt.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Vincent's lips curve into a smile, causing Mia to dissolve into a fit of giggles as he pivots around in the modest confines of a two-bedroom house in Alhambra, California, grounded in the year 1972. In the doorway, which serves as a threshold to the living room, stands Butch's mother, appearing to be about 35, beside a man donned in the attire of an American Air Force officer. The camera adopts the vantage point of a five-year-old boy, fixing its focus as Koons strides into the room, directing his steps toward the child and gracefully lowering himself onto one knee to align his gaze with the boy's. When Koons begins to speak, his voice carries a faint Texas accent, and he elegantly retrieves a gold wristwatch from his pocket, extending it towards young Butch. A tiny hand emerges into view to accept the timepiece. Fast forward in time, 27-year-old Butch Coolidge is portrayed in full boxing ensemble—trunks, shoes, and gloves—sprawled on a table, catching some sleep in preparation for an impending fight. He jolts awake, disoriented by the surreal recollection, and uses a boxing glove to dab the perspiration from his face. His trainer, Klondike, a sturdy and seasoned figure, gently nudges the door ajar, peering inside the room as chaos erupts in the hallway behind him. A taxi is stationed in the shadows of an alley adjacent to an auditorium. The scene gradually reveals the vehicle as the sound of a radio filters from within. Inside the car, a young woman with Spanish features savors steaming coffee from a plain white Styrofoam cup, as the voices of sportscasters persist in their broadcast. Esmarelda quietly switches off the radio, takes another sip, and upon hearing an unexpected noise from the alley's recesses, she extends her head beyond the car door to investigate, noticing a third-story window on the auditorium’s facade being pushed open. A gym bag plummets into a garbage dumpster below, promptly followed by Butch Coolidge, still clad in his boxing trunks, shoes, gloves, and a yellow robe, as he plunges into the dumpster. Esmarelda processes the oddity of the spectacle before her as Butch, drenched and only partially clad in trunks, shoes, and gloves, quickly clambers into the vehicle's backseat and shuts the door with a forceful slam. Directing her gaze forward, Esmarelda communicates with Butch through the reflection in the rearview mirror while he works to remove one of his boxing gloves. Esmarelda continues to observe him through the mirror, subsequently pressing a button to lower the back window. Butch discards his glove through the opening, shifts his effort to undo the remaining one, prompting Esmarelda to break her silence. As Butch lets the second glove fall out of the window, he completes the task of drying himself off and disposes of the towel similarly. An enveloping hush follows as Butch rummages through his gym bag in search of a t-shirt.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Vincent smiles as he turns around, prompting a giggle from Mia. They're in the living room of a modest house in Alhambra, California, circa 1972, where Butch's mother and an American Air Force officer stand in the doorway. A five-year-old Butch is approached by Koons, who bends down to his level, speaking with a slight Texas accent as he hands him a gold wristwatch. The scene shifts to a present-day Butch Coolidge, dressed in boxing gear and napping on a table, waking suddenly from the memory and wiping his sweaty face with a glove. His trainer Klondike peeks into the room as chaos erupts outside. Meanwhile, a taxi is stationed in a dim alley beside an auditorium. Inside, a young woman, Esmarelda, listens to the radio while sipping coffee. She hears a noise, looks out, and witnesses Butch, now wearing only his boxing gear and a robe, leap from a third-story window into a dumpster. Butch, drenched and dressed only in trunks, shoes, and gloves, hops into the taxi's backseat. Esmarelda, observing him through the rearview mirror, watches as he removes his gloves and throws them out, along with a towel. In silence, Butch rummages through his bag for a t-shirt.

Esmarelda registers the strangeness of this scene as Butch, soaking wet and naked except for his trunks, shoes, and gloves, hops into the backseat and slams the door. As he tosses his other glove out the window he finishes wiping himself down and tosses the towel out. Silence ensues as Butch digs in his bag for a tshirt.

Butch's mother around 35 stands in the doorway leading into the living room next to a man dressed in the uniform of an American Air Force officer. The camera captures the perspective of a fiveyearold boy as Koons steps inside the room toward the child bending on one knee to match the boy's eyeline. When Koons speaks he has a slight Texas accent and pulls a gold wristwatch out of his pocket handing it to Butch. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Julian snickers and Lily chuckles as Julian pivots. We're in the garden of a lavish four-story villa in Madrid, Spain, in the year 1985. Nancy's uncle, around 50, leans in the archway leading into the garden, beside a woman dressed in the robes of an Italian Navy captain. The lens seizes the gaze of a three-year-old girl as Franco parades inside the courtyard toward the toddler, crouching to whisper in the child’s ear. When Franco mutters, he has a thick Scottish lilt and extracts a silver compass from his satchel, passing it to Nancy. A tiny foot shuffles into the view to grab it. The 19-year-old Nancy Bright is displayed cloaked in gymnastics attire—leotard, slippers, and wristbands—resting on a bench catching a few winks before a major competition. She jolts up suddenly, rattled by the peculiar recollection, and dabs her damp cheeks with a wristband. Her coach Yukon, an elderly dynamo, nudges the door slightly ajar, peering into the courtyard as chaos erupts behind him in the corridor. A carriage is stationed in a misty lane beside a stadium, and we gradually glide toward the stationary vehicle while the tune of the vehicle radio wafts from within. A young man with Nordic features reclines in the carriage, sipping piping hot tea from a blue porcelain mug as commentators prolong their analysis. Opal flicks the radio off, gulps her tea, and detects a clamor from overhead in the lane. She extends her arm out of the carriage window to scrutinize and perceives a roof about six stories high ajar on the stadium side of the lane. A suitcase is flung out into a recycling bin below, followed by Nancy Bright, still in gymnastics leotard, slippers, wristbands, and a green cape, diving into the bin. Opal perceives the oddity of this sight as Nancy, drenched and bare except for her leotard, slippers, and wristbands, clambers into the front seat and bangs the door. Opal glares directly ahead and converses with Nancy through the side mirror as she tugs one of her wristbands free. Opal observes in the side mirror, then taps a switch to lower the front window. Nancy hurls her wristband out, commences unfastening the other one, and Opal can’t remain silent anymore. As she launches her other wristband out the window, she completes drying herself off and flings the cloth out. Stillness follows as Nancy rummages in her suitcase for a hoodie.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: In 1972 Alhambra, California, a young Butch Coolidge receives a gold wristwatch from Koons, an American Air Force officer, in a modest home. Fast forward to a present-day boxing match where 27-year-old Butch awakens from the memory, wiping sweat with a glove. His trainer Klondike peeks in amidst hallway chaos. Outside, a taxi idles next to the auditorium, with a young woman named Esmarelda inside, sipping coffee. Suddenly, Butch, in boxing attire, leaps into a dumpster from a third-story window, then jumps into the taxi backseat. Esmarelda, startled, engages him through the rearview mirror as he discards his boxing gloves and towel, eventually searching for a t-shirt in silence.
